aquarium_calculator.title: Aquarium Calculator
aquarium_calculator.description: Calculate fish tank volume and capacity.
aquarium_calculator.empty_state: Enter dimensions to calculate tank capacity
tips: Cycle the tank before adding fish

howItWorks.title: How the Aquarium Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines your aquarium's water volume and recommends the appropriate number of fish based on the one-inch-per-gallon rule, adjusted for fish size.
steps: Enter your tank's length, width, and height in centimeters
Select the average size of fish you plan to keep
Click Calculate to see volume in liters and gallons
Review recommended fish capacity and equipment sizing

useCases: Planning a new aquarium setup and determining tank size needs
Calculating how many fish can safely live in your tank
Sizing filters, heaters, and other equipment properly
Converting between metric and imperial water measurements
seoTips: Always understock rather than overstock your aquarium
Consider fish adult size, not purchase size when calculating
Factor in decorations and substrate that reduce water volume
Different fish species have varying space requirements
Larger tanks are more stable and easier to maintain
commonMistakes: Calculating based on juvenile fish size instead of adult size
Not accounting for decorations reducing actual water volume
Overstocking the tank leading to poor water quality
Ignoring species-specific space requirements

faqs.question: How many fish can I put in my aquarium?
faqs.answer: The general rule is one inch of fish per gallon of water for small fish. However, this varies by species, and larger fish need proportionally more space.

faqs.question: What filter size do I need for my tank?
faqs.answer: Choose a filter rated for 4-6 times your tank volume per hour. For a 100L tank, select a filter rated for 400-600 L/h.

faqs.question: How do I calculate heater wattage?
faqs.answer: Use approximately 3-5 watts per gallon of water. A 20-gallon tank needs a 60-100 watt heater.

faqs.question: Does tank shape affect fish capacity?
faqs.answer: Yes, surface area matters more than volume for oxygen exchange. Wider, shallower tanks can support more fish than tall, narrow tanks of the same volume.

faqs.question: Should I fill my tank completely?
faqs.answer: Leave 1-2 inches at the top for gas exchange and to prevent jumping fish from escaping. This also allows for equipment placement.

bird_cage_calculator.title: Bird Cage Size Calculator
bird_cage_calculator.description: Calculate appropriate bird cage dimensions for various bird types.
bird_cage_calculator.empty_state: Enter bird details to calculate minimum cage size

howItWorks.title: How the Bird Cage Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Minimum cage size based on bird wingspan × 2-3 times
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator recommends minimum cage dimensions based on bird species and quantity, ensuring adequate space for flight, exercise, and mental stimulation.
steps: Select your bird species from the dropdown menu
Enter the number of birds you plan to house together
Click Calculate to see minimum cage dimensions
Review bar spacing and perch diameter recommendations

useCases: Choosing the right cage size when adopting a new bird
Upgrading an existing cage for better bird welfare
Planning a multi-bird housing setup
Ensuring proper bar spacing for bird safety
seoTips: Bigger is always better when it comes to bird cages
Horizontal space is more important than vertical for most birds
Bar spacing must prevent head entrapment
Multiple perches of varying diameters promote foot health
Consider cage placement away from drafts and direct sunlight
commonMistakes: Buying a cage that is too small for the bird species
Choosing wrong bar spacing that can trap bird's head
Not considering room for toys and accessories
Prioritizing height over width for flying birds

faqs.question: What is the minimum cage size for a budgie?
faqs.answer: A single budgie needs at least 18x18x18 inches, but larger is better. For multiple budgies, add 50% more space per additional bird.

faqs.question: Why does bar spacing matter?
faqs.answer: Incorrect bar spacing can allow birds to escape or get their heads stuck. Small birds need 1/2 inch spacing, medium birds 5/8-3/4 inch, and large parrots 1-1.5 inches.

faqs.question: Should I get a round or rectangular cage?
faqs.answer: Rectangular cages are better as they provide corners where birds feel secure. Round cages can cause psychological stress and offer less usable space.

faqs.question: How many birds can share one cage?
faqs.answer: This depends on species compatibility and cage size. Generally, same-species birds can cohabitate, but increase cage size by 50% per additional bird.

faqs.question: What perch diameter is best?
faqs.answer: Perches should vary in diameter so the bird's foot doesn't always grip the same way. This prevents foot problems and arthritis.

bird_cage_calculator.error_invalid_birds: Please enter a valid number of birds

bird_cage_size_calculator.title: Bird Cage Size Calculator - Free Aviary Planning Tool
bird_cage_size_calculator.description: Calculate appropriate bird cage dimensions. Free online tool for parakeets, parrots, and all pet bird types.
tips: Horizontal is better than vertical for small birds
Place cage in a quiet and safe spot

howItWorks.title: How the Bird Cage Size Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Minimum cage size = Bird wingspan × 2.5 for width, wingspan × 3 for length
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines the minimum cage dimensions required for healthy bird housing based on species size and number of birds. Proper cage sizing ensures birds can spread their wings fully and have adequate space for exercise and mental stimulation.

steps.name: Select Bird Species
steps.text: Choose your bird type from the dropdown menu to get species-specific recommendations

steps.name: Enter Bird Count
steps.text: Input the number of birds you plan to house in the same cage

steps.name: Calculate Dimensions
steps.text: Click calculate to receive minimum cage dimensions in inches and centimeters

steps.name: Review Requirements
steps.text: Check bar spacing and perch diameter recommendations for your bird species

useCases.title: New Bird Owner Planning
useCases.description: First-time bird owners can determine the right cage size before purchasing, ensuring their new pet has adequate living space from day one.

useCases.title: Cage Upgrade Assessment
useCases.description: Current bird owners can evaluate whether their existing cage meets minimum requirements or if an upgrade is needed for better bird welfare.

useCases.title: Multi-Bird Housing
useCases.description: Calculate space requirements when adding birds to an existing flock or planning a multi-bird setup with compatible species.

useCases.title: Aviary Design
useCases.description: Plan indoor or outdoor aviaries with proper dimensions for breeding pairs or larger bird communities.

seoTips: Always choose a cage larger than the minimum recommendation when possible
Horizontal space is more important than height for most bird species
Bar spacing must prevent birds from getting their heads stuck between bars
Consider the cage door size for easy cleaning and bird handling
Natural perches of varying diameters promote foot health and prevent arthritis
commonMistakes: Buying decorative round cages that provide less usable space and cause psychological stress
Selecting bar spacing too wide for small birds, creating escape or injury risks
Prioritizing cage height over width for species that fly horizontally
Not accounting for space needed for food bowls, water dishes, and toys
Placing multiple territorial species together without adequate space separation

faqs.question: What is the minimum cage size for a parakeet or budgie?
faqs.answer: A single parakeet needs at least 18 x 18 x 18 inches (45 x 45 x 45 cm). However, larger is always better. For each additional bird, increase the size by 50%. Budgies are active flyers and benefit greatly from extra horizontal space.

faqs.question: Why are rectangular cages better than round ones?
faqs.answer: Rectangular cages provide corners where birds feel secure, offer more usable floor and wall space, and allow for proper perch placement at varying heights. Round cages eliminate these security corners and can cause psychological stress in birds.

faqs.question: How do I determine the correct bar spacing?
faqs.answer: Bar spacing depends on bird size: finches and canaries need 1/4 to 1/2 inch spacing, budgies and lovebirds need 1/2 inch, cockatiels need 1/2 to 5/8 inch, and larger parrots need 3/4 to 1 inch or more. Incorrect spacing can lead to head entrapment or escape.

faqs.question: Can different bird species share the same cage?
faqs.answer: Some species can cohabitate if they have similar sizes and temperaments. However, you must significantly increase cage size and provide multiple feeding stations. Never house aggressive species together, and always research species compatibility before mixing.

faqs.question: How often should I clean the bird cage?
faqs.answer: Daily spot cleaning of droppings and food debris is essential. Weekly thorough cleaning includes washing perches and toys. Monthly deep cleaning involves disinfecting the entire cage. A clean environment prevents disease and promotes bird health.

rabbit_care_calculator.title: Rabbit Care Calculator - Free Bunny Diet and Space Tool
rabbit_care_calculator.description: Calculate rabbit feeding and living space needs. Free online bunny care calculator for healthy pet rabbits.
tips: Fresh water available at all times
rabbit_care_calculator.empty_state: Enter rabbit details to calculate its needs
rabbit_care_calculator.footer_note: Estimated needs based on breed averages. Individual needs may vary.

howItWorks.title: How Rabbit Care Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Daily needs based on body weight and size category
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines optimal diet portions and housing requirements for rabbits based on their size, ensuring proper nutrition and living space.
steps: Enter your rabbit's weight
Select their size category
View daily hay, pellet, and vegetable amounts
Check minimum hutch dimensions

useCases: Planning daily feeding amounts for rabbits
Selecting appropriate hutch or enclosure size
Ensuring balanced diet proportions
Budgeting for rabbit care supplies
seoTips: Hay should make up 80% of a rabbit's diet
Unlimited Timothy hay is essential
Pellets should be limited based on weight
Fresh vegetables provide necessary nutrients
Rabbits need more space than most people expect
commonMistakes: Overfeeding pellets relative to hay
Using too small of an enclosure
Not providing unlimited hay access
Feeding wrong vegetables (iceberg lettuce is harmful)

faqs.question: How much hay should a rabbit eat?
faqs.answer: Rabbits should have unlimited access to hay. They should eat a pile about the size of their body daily. Hay is essential for dental and digestive health.

faqs.question: How many pellets should a rabbit get?
faqs.answer: Adult rabbits need about 1/4 cup of pellets per 2.5 kg of body weight daily. Young rabbits can have unlimited pellets until 6-7 months.

faqs.question: What size hutch does a rabbit need?
faqs.answer: Minimum is 4x their body length when stretched out. Bigger is always better. Rabbits need room to hop, stretch, and stand on hind legs.

faqs.question: What vegetables can rabbits eat?
faqs.answer: Leafy greens like romaine, cilantro, parsley, and herbs. Avoid iceberg lettuce and limit high-sugar vegetables like carrots.

faqs.question: Do rabbits need exercise outside their cage?
faqs.answer: Yes! Rabbits need 3-4 hours of exercise outside their enclosure daily. A rabbit-proofed room or secure pen works well.

Feeding wrong vegetables (iceberg lettuce is harmful)

faqs.question: How much hay should a rabbit eat?
faqs.answer: Unlimited! A rabbit should eat a pile of hay about their body size daily. Hay is essential for dental and digestive health.

faqs.question: How many pellets per day?
faqs.answer: About 1/4 cup per 5 lbs of body weight for adult rabbits. Pellets should be high-fiber Timothy-based, not alfalfa (for adults).

faqs.question: What size hutch does a rabbit need?
faqs.answer: Minimum is 4x their body length when stretched out. Bigger is always better. Rabbits need room to hop, stretch, and stand on hind legs.

faqs.question: What vegetables can rabbits eat?
faqs.answer: Leafy greens like romaine, cilantro, parsley, and herbs. Avoid iceberg lettuce and limit high-sugar vegetables like carrots.

faqs.question: Do rabbits need exercise outside their cage?
faqs.answer: Yes! Rabbits need 3-4 hours of exercise outside their enclosure daily. A rabbit-proofed room or secure pen works well.

reptile_tank_calculator.title: Reptile Tank Calculator - Terrarium Size and Setup
reptile_tank_calculator.description: Calculate terrarium size for reptiles and amphibians. Free online tank calculator for snakes, lizards, and turtles.
tips: Maintain temperature gradient in the tank

howItWorks.title: How Reptile Tank Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Tank size = Species requirements + Adult size considerations
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator recommends terrarium dimensions, heating, and humidity requirements based on reptile species, ensuring proper husbandry for your pet.
steps: Select your reptile species
Enter the reptile's size or age
View recommended tank dimensions
Check temperature, humidity, and lighting requirements

useCases: Selecting appropriate enclosure size for new reptiles
Planning habitat upgrades as reptiles grow
Ensuring proper temperature gradients
Setting up correct lighting and humidity
seoTips: Always size tanks for adult size, not current size
Temperature gradients are essential for thermoregulation
UVB lighting is crucial for most species
Humidity requirements vary greatly by species
Ventilation is as important as heat and humidity
commonMistakes: Buying tanks for juvenile size instead of adult
Not providing a temperature gradient
Using wrong substrate for the species
Forgetting to replace UVB bulbs regularly

faqs.question: How big should my reptile tank be?
faqs.answer: Generally, the enclosure should be at least 1.5-2x the reptile's adult length. Arboreal species need height; terrestrial species need floor space.

faqs.question: Why do reptiles need a temperature gradient?
faqs.answer: Reptiles are cold-blooded and regulate body temperature by moving between warm and cool areas. One end should be the basking spot, the other end cooler.

faqs.question: Do all reptiles need UVB lighting?
faqs.answer: Most diurnal reptiles need UVB for vitamin D3 synthesis. Nocturnal species and some snakes may not require it, but it's rarely harmful.

faqs.question: How often should I replace UVB bulbs?
faqs.answer: Every 6-12 months, even if they still produce light. UVB output decreases over time even when the bulb appears to work normally.

faqs.question: What substrate should I use?
faqs.answer: This depends on species. Arid species may use sand or tile, tropical species need moisture-retaining substrate. Avoid cedar and pine shavings for all reptiles.

reptile-tank-calculator.title: Reptile Tank Calculator - Terrarium Size and Setup
reptile-tank-calculator.description: Calculate terrarium size for reptiles and amphibians. Free online tank calculator for snakes, lizards, and turtles.

Ventilation is as important as heat and humidity
commonMistakes: Buying tanks for juvenile size instead of adult
Not providing a temperature gradient
Using wrong substrate for the species
Forgetting to replace UVB bulbs regularly

faqs.question: How big should my reptile tank be?
faqs.answer: Generally, the enclosure should be at least 1.5-2x the reptile's adult length. Arboreal species need height; terrestrial species need floor space.

faqs.question: Why is a temperature gradient important?
faqs.answer: Reptiles are cold-blooded and need a warm basking spot and cooler area to regulate body temperature. The gradient allows them to thermoregulate.

faqs.question: Do all reptiles need UVB lighting?
faqs.answer: Most do, especially diurnal species. UVB is essential for vitamin D3 synthesis and calcium absorption. Some nocturnal species may not require it.

faqs.question: What humidity level do reptiles need?
faqs.answer: It varies greatly. Desert species: 20-40%. Tropical species: 60-80%+. Research your specific species requirements carefully.

faqs.question: How often should I clean the tank?
faqs.answer: Spot clean daily (remove waste and uneaten food). Deep clean monthly, disinfecting surfaces and replacing substrate as needed.
